    Published List Experiments

    Below is a list compiled by Graeme Blair, Alex Coppock, and Margaret Moor of all published list experiments. If your published list experiment is not included, please email Margaret at xx.

    Bibliography

    Ahart, Allison M, and Paul R Sackett. 2004. “A New Method of Examining Relationships Between Individual Difference Measures and Sensitive Behavior Criteria: Evaluating the Unmatched Count Technique.” Organizational Research Methods 7 (1). Sage Publications: 101–14. http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1094428103259557?journalCode=orma.

    Ahlquist, John S, Kenneth R Mayer, and Simon Jackman. 2014. “Alien Abduction and Voter Impersonation in the 2012 Us General Election: Evidence from a Survey List Experiment.” Election Law Journal 13 (4). Mary Ann Liebert, Inc. 140 Huguenot Street, 3rd Floor New Rochelle, NY 10801 USA: 460–75. http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/elj.2013.0231.

    Antin, Judd, and Aaron Shaw. 2012. “Social Desirability Bias and Self-Reports of Motivation: A Study of Amazon Mechanical Turk in the Us and India.” In Proceedings of the Sigchi Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, 2925–34. ACM. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/254005198_Social_desirability_bias_and_self-reports_of_motivation_A_study_of_Amazon_Mechanical_Turk_in_the_US_and_India.

    Arentoft, Alyssa, Kathleen Van Dyk, April D Thames, Philip Sayegh, Nicholas Thaler, Daniel Schonfeld, Joseph LaBrie, and Charles H Hinkin. 2016. “Comparing the Unmatched Count Technique and Direct Self-Report for Sensitive Health-Risk Behaviors in Hiv+ Adults.” AIDS Care 28 (3). Taylor & Francis: 370–75. http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09540121.2015.1090538.

    Aronow, Peter M., Alexander Coppock, Forrest W. Crawford, and Donald P. Green. 2015. “Combining List Experiment and Direct Question Estimates of Sensitive Behavior Prevalence.” Journal of Survey Statistics and Methodology 3 (1). Oxford University Press: 43–66. https://academic.oup.com/jssam/article/3/1/43/915561/Combining-List-Experiment-and-Direct-Question#15842185.

    Ash, Konstantin. 2013. “Identity Group Allegiance in Civil Wars.” New York Times. https://escholarship.org/uc/item/8qv6r3t7.

    Bausch, Andrew W, Anna O Pechenkina, and Kiron Skinner. 2016. “Limitations of List Experiments in Post-Conflict Zones.” https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2821289.

    Berinsky, Adam J. 2017. “Telling the Truth About Believing the Lies? Evidence for the Limited Prevalence of Expressive Survey Responding.” The Journal of Politics 80 (1). University of Chicago Press Chicago, IL. http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/pdfplus/10.1086/694258.

    Biemer, Paul, and Gordon Brown. 2005. “Model-Based Estimation of Drug Use Prevalence Using Item Count Data.” Journal of Official Statistics 21 (2). Statistics Sweden (SCB): 287–308. http://www.sverigeisiffror.scb.se/contentassets/ca21efb41fee47d293bbee5bf7be7fb3/model-based-estimation-of-drug-use-prevalence-using-item-count-data.pdf.

    Blair, Graeme, Kosuke Imai, and Jason Lyall. 2014. “Comparing and Combining List and Endorsement Experiments: Evidence from Afghanistan.” American Journal of Political Science 58 (4). Wiley Online Library: 1043–63. http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ajps.12086/abstract.

    Braithwaite, Jeremy. 2008. “Self-Reported Alcohol Consumption and Sexual Behavior in Males and Females: Using the Unmatched-Count Technique to Examine Reporting Practices of Socially Sensitive Subjects in a Sample of University Students.” Journal of Alcohol and Drug Education 52 (2). American Alcohol; Drug Information Foundation: 49–72. https://eric.ed.gov/?id=EJ841364.

    Bratton, Michael, Boniface Dulani, and Eldred Masunungure. 2016. “Detecting Manipulation in Authoritarian Elections: Survey-Based Methods in Zimbabwe.” Electoral Studies 42. Elsevier: 10–21. http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0261379416000068.

    Brierley, Sarah Anne. 2017. “Politicians and Bureaucrats: The Politics of Development and Corruption in Ghana.” PhD thesis, UCLA. https://escholarship.org/uc/item/3kw5280p.

    Brooke, Steven. 2017. “Sectarianism and Social Conformity: Evidence from Egypt.” Political Research Quarterly 70 (4). SAGE Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA: 848–60. http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1065912917717641.

    Brownback, Andy, and Aaron M Novotny. 2017. “Social Desirability Bias and Polling Errors in the 2016 Presidential Election.” https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3001360.

    Brueckner, Hannah, Ann Morning, and Alondra Nelson. 2005. “The Expression of Biological Concepts of Race.” In Annual Meeting of the American Sociological Association, Philadelphia, Pa. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/252606297_THE_EXPRESSION_OF_BIOLOGICAL_CONCEPTS_OF_RACE1.

    Burden, Barry C, Yoshikuni Ono, and Masahiro Yamada. 2017. “Reassessing Public Support for a Female President.” The Journal of Politics 79 (3). University of Chicago Press Chicago, IL: 1073–8. https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2901548.

    Cappelen, Cornelius, and Tor Midtbø. 2016. “Intra-Eu Labour Migration and Support for the Norwegian Welfare State.” European Sociological Review 32 (6). Oxford University Press: 691–703. https://academic.oup.com/esr/article/32/6/691/2525461/Intra-EU-Labour-Migration-and-Support-for-the#supplementary-data.

    Coffman, Katherine B, Lucas C Coffman, and Keith M Marzilli Ericson. 2016. “The Size of the Lgbt Population and the Magnitude of Antigay Sentiment Are Substantially Underestimated.” Management Science 63 (10). INFORMS: 3168–86. https://doi.org/10.1287/ mnsc.2016.2503.

    Comşa, Mircea, and Camil Postelnicu. 2012. “Measuring Social Desirability Effects on Self-Reported Turnout Using the Item Count Technique.” International Journal of Public Opinion Research 25 (2). Oxford University Press: 153–72. https://academic.oup.com/ijpor/article/25/2/153/692213/Measuring-Social-Desirability-Effects-on-Self.

    Conley, Dalton, and Brian J McCabe. 2011. “Body Mass Index and Physical Attractiveness: Evidence from a Combination Image-Alteration/List Experiment.” Sociological Methods & Research 40 (1). Sage Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA: 6–31. http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0049124110390762.

    Coppock, Alexander. 2017. “Did Shy Trump Supporters Bias the 2016 Polls? Evidence from a Nationally-Representative List Experiment.” Statistics, Politics and Policy 8 (1). De Gruyter: 29–40. https://acoppock.github.io/papers/Coppock_shytrump.pdf.

    Corstange, Daniel. 2008. “Sensitive Questions, Truthful Answers? Modeling the List Experiment with Listit.” Political Analysis 17 (1). Oxford University Press: 45–63. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228295908_Sensitive_Questions_Truthful_Answers_Modeling_the_List_Experiment_with_LISTIT.

    ———. 2017. “Clientelism in Competitive and Uncompetitive Elections.” Comparative Political Studies 51 (1). SAGE Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA: 76–104. http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0010414017695332.

    Coutts, Elisabeth, and Ben Jann. 2011. “Sensitive Questions in Online Surveys: Experimental Results for the Randomized Response Technique (Rrt) and the Unmatched Count Technique (Uct).” Sociological Methods & Research 40 (1). Sage Publications Sage CA: Los Angeles, CA: 169–93. http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0049124110390768.

    Creighton, Mathew J, and Amaney Jamal. 2015. “Does Islam Play a Role in Anti-Immigrant Sentiment? An Experimental Approach.” Social Science Research 53. Elsevier: 89–103. http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/imre.12091/full.

    Creighton, Mathew J, Amaney Jamal, and Natalia C Malancu. 2015. “Has Opposition to Immigration Increased in the United States After the Economic Crisis? An Experimental Approach.” International Migration Review 49 (3). Wiley Online Library: 727–56. http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0049089X15000812.

    Çarkoğlu, Ali, and S Erdem Aytaç. 2015. “Who Gets Targeted for Vote-Buying? Evidence from an Augmented List Experiment in Turkey.” European Political Science Review 7 (4). Cambridge University Press: 547–66.

    Dai, Yaoyao. 2014. “Do Citizens in Authoritarian Countries Censor Themselves?” PhD thesis, Duke University. https://dukespace.lib.duke.edu/dspace/bitstream/handle/10161/8837/Dai_duke_0066N_12430.pdf?sequence=1.

    Dalton, Dan R, James C Wimbush, and Catherine M Daily. 1994. “Using the Unmatched Count Technique (Uct) to Estimate Base Rates for Sensitive Behavior.” Personnel Psychology 47 (4). Wiley Online Library: 817–29. http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1744-6570.1994.tb01578.x/abstract.

    De Cao, Elisabetta, and Clemens Herman Maria Lutz. 2014. Sensitive Survey Questions: Measuring Attitudes Regarding Female Circumcision Through a List Experiment. University of Groningen, Faculty of Economics; Business. http://www.rug.nl/research/som-ri/som-research-reports/som-research-reports-2014/14017-eef-def.pdf.

    De Jonge, Chad P Kiewiet, and David W Nickerson. 2014. “Artificial Inflation or Deflation? Assessing the Item Count Technique in Comparative Surveys.” Political Behavior 36 (3). Springer: 659–82. https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11109-013-9249-x.

    Diaz-Cayeros, Alberto, Beatriz Magaloni, Aila M Matanock, and Vidal Romero. 2011. “Living in Fear: The Dynamics of Extortion in Mexico’s Criminal Insurgency.” In Ponencia Presentada En Violence, Drugs and Governance: Mexican Security in Comparative Perspective Conference, Stanford, Octubre. http://cddrl.fsi.stanford.edu/publication/living-fear-dynamics-extortion-mexicos-criminal-insurgency.

    Dion, Michelle L, and Jordi Díez. 2016. “Social Desirability Bias and Question Framing Effects: Evidence from a Combined List and Framing Experiment on Same-Sex Marriage Support in Argentina.” In. Fourth Annual Toronto Political Behaviour Workshop. http://rubenson.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Dion-Diez.pdf.

    Donovan, Todd. 2011. “Does Leading in Opinion Polls Make a Candidate More Appealing? Experimenting with the Microfoundations of Momentum.” In. Paper prepared for the 2011 Pacific Northwest Political Science Association meeting. https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Todd_Donovan/publication/254067703_Microfoundations_of_Momentum_Does_Leading_in_Polls_Make_Candidates_More_Appealing/links/571a587308aee3ddc568f4eb.pdf.

    Droitcour, Judith, Rachel A Caspar, Michael L Hubbard, Teresa L Parsley, Wendy Visscher, and Trena M Ezzati. 1991. “The Item Count Technique as a Method of Indirect Questioning: A Review of Its Development and a Case Study Application.” Measurement Errors in Surveys.     Eriksen, Steffen, Clemens Lutz, and Getaw Tadesse. 2017. “Social Desirability, Opportunism and Actual Support for Farmers’ Market Organisations in Ethiopia.” The Journal of Development Studies. Taylor & Francis, 1–16. http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00220388.2017.1299138.
